travel.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to go from one place to another, or to several places, especially ones that are far away
travel.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Someday I’d like to travel abroad.
He’d travelled far, but he’d travelled light (=without taking many possessions).
He has travelled extensively in China.
We travelled by train across Eastern Europe.
We’re planning to travel across America this summer.
travel.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to go to most parts of the world or of a particular country
travel.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to go a particular distance or at a particular speed
travel.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: They travelled 200 miles on the first day.
The train was travelling at 100 mph.
travel.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to be passed quickly from one person or place to another
travel.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if your eyes travel over something, you look at different parts of it
travel.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: His gaze travelled over her face.
travel.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to move at a particular speed or in a particular direction
travel.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to take more than three steps while you are holding the ball in basketball
travel.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Only the affluent could afford to take vacations or to travel abroad.
He travelled extensively in Europe studying geology.
The idea was to travel light, so Travis allowed her to pack only one change of clothing.
travel.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: to travel
to go from one place to another, especially places that are far apart
We travelled to Russia by train.
I love to travel.
go
to go somewhere – often used instead of travel
We’re going to Greece for our holidays this year.
He’s gone to London on business.
It’s quicker to go by plane.
commute
to travel to work or school
She commutes to work by bicycle.
cross
to travel across a very large area, for example a desert or ocean
The slaves crossed the Atlantic in the holds of the ships.
tour
to travel in order to visit many different places, especially as part of a holiday
They’re touring Europe by coach.
go trekking
to do a long and difficult walk in a place far from towns and cities
They went trekking in the mountains.
She’s been trekking in Nepal a couple of times.
go backpacking
to travel to a lot of different places, carrying your clothes with you in your rucksack
He went backpacking in Australia.
roam
to travel or move around an area with no clear purpose or direction, usually for a long time
When he was young, he roamed from one country to another.
The tribes used to roam around freely, without any fixed territory.
to travel, especially a long distance
He journeyed on horseback through Palestine.
people who travel
traveller
someone who is travelling a long distance
Weary travellers waited at the airport.
My aunt was a great traveller  (=she travelled a lot).
tourist
someone who is travelling somewhere for a holiday
During the summer, over a million tourists visit the island each year.
passenger
someone who is travelling in a vehicle, plane, ship etc but not driving it or working on it
The driver and two passengers were killed in the crash.
commuter
someone who travels to work every day
commuters on the train to London
backpacker
someone who travels to a lot of different places, carrying their clothes etc in a rucksack
The hostels are great for backpackers.
explorer
someone who travels to places that people have not visited before
Potatoes were brought to England by explorers such as Sir Francis Drake and Sir Walter Raleigh.
travel.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The new job involves a fair amount of travel.
travel.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: There has been a major increase in air travel during the last twenty years.
The measures were introduced to make rail travel safer.
The price is £98, inclusive of coach travel.
The job offers opportunities for foreign travel.
Long-distance travel is becoming much more common these days.
Business travel often took him away from his family.
Large rockets are used for space travel and exploration.
The storms have had a huge effect on the country’s travel industry.
I still have to make all the travel arrangements.
They offered to pay my travel expenses.
You are strongly advised to take out travel insurance.
Kyushu looks so lovely in the travel books.
I find the train a more comfortable mode of travel.
travel.translation[1].note_box[1].items[: You use travel to talk in general about the activity of travelling
Long-distance travel has become much cheaper
My interests are travel and photography
Travel is only used as an uncountable noun
a travel
the travel
travels
Someone’s travels are their journeys to many different places
On her travels, she visited Egypt, Jordan, and South Africa
I’ll call you when I get back from my travels
travels
Travels is always used as a plural noun in this meaning
her travel
my travel
You use trip to talk about an occasion when someone travels somewhere
He has gone to New York on a business trip
They have made several trips to Europe
Trip is a countable noun and can be used in the singular with ‘a’ or in the plural Don’t use travel in this meaning You say
Have a nice trip!
Have a nice travel!
travel.translation[2].definitions[0].def: the activity of going from one place to another, or to several different places, by air, road, rail etc
travel.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The drop in revenue reflected lower levels ofdomestic travel (=within your own country).
American Express has strengthened its lead in thecorporate travel business.
Air travel continued its recovery from a year earlier.
travel.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to go from one place to another, or to several different places, by air, road, rail etc
travel.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: As part of his job, he has to travel abroad extensively.
Channel Tunnel trains travel between London and Paris in 3 hours.
